greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of n avoiding equidistant 3-term arithmetic progressions.
link: Fausto A. C. Cariboni, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..300 (terms 0..150 from Joerg Arndt and Alois P. Heinz)
example: Note that the fourth partition has the arithmetic progression 1,2,3, but not in equidistant positions.
maple: b:= proc(n, i, l) local j;
for j from 2 to iquo(nops(l)+1, 2) do
if l[1]-l[j]=l[j]-l[2*j-1] then return 0 fi od;
mathematica: b[n_, i_, l_] := b[n, i, l] = Module[{j}, For[ j = 2 , j <= Quotient[ Length[l] + 1, 2] , j++, If[ l[[1]] - l[[j]] == l[[j]] - l[[2*j - 1]] , Return[0]]]; If[n == 0, 1, If[i < 1, 0, b[n, i - 1, l] + If[i > n, 0, b[n - i, i, Prepend[l, i]]]]]];
Table[a[n], {n, 0, 40}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, May 21 2018, translated from Maple *)
xref: Cf. A238571 (partitions avoiding any 3-term arithmetic progression).
Cf. A238424 (partitions avoiding three consecutive parts in arithmetic progression).
results.author: _Joerg Arndt_ and _Alois P. Heinz_, Mar 01 2014
